description: Enterprise techniques used by Turla, ATT&CK group G0010 v1.3
name: Turla (G0010)

techniques.comment: Turla RPC backdoors can impersonate or steal process tokens before executing commands.[5]
Turla has used HTTP and HTTPS for C2 communications.[4][6]
Turla has encrypted files stolen from connected USB drives into a RAR file before exfiltration.[7]

A Turla Javascript backdoor added a local_update_check value under the Registry key HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run to establish persistence. Additionally, a Turla custom executable containing Metasploit shellcode is saved to the Startup folder to gain persistence.[4][6]
Turla established persistence by adding a Shell value under the Registry key HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion]Winlogon.[4]
Turla may attempt to connect to systems within a victim's network using net use commands and a predefined list or collection of passwords.[1]

Turla has used PowerShell to execute commands/scripts, in some cases via a custom executable or code from Empire's PSInject.[6][5][7] Turla has also used PowerShell scripts to load and execute malware in memory.
Turla RPC backdoors have used cmd.exe to execute commands.[5][7]
Turla has used VBS scripts throughout its operations.[7]
Turla has gathered credentials from the Windows Credential Manager tool.[7]
Turla RPC backdoors can upload files from victim machines.[5]
Turla RPC backdoors can collect files from USB thumb drives.[5][7]
Turla has used a custom decryption routine, which pulls key and salt values from other artifacts such as a WMI filter or PowerShell Profile, to decode encrypted PowerShell payloads.[5]
Turla has used PowerShell profiles to maintain persistence on an infected machine.[5]
Turla has used WMI event filters and consumers to establish persistence.[5]
Turla has used WebDAV to upload stolen USB files to a cloud drive.[7]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover files in specific locations on the hard disk %TEMP% directory, the current user's desktop, and in the Program Files directory.[1] Turla RPC backdoors have also searched for files matching the lPH*.dll pattern.[5]
Turla has used a AMSI bypass, which patches the in-memory amsi.dll, in PowerShell scripts to bypass Windows antimalware products.[5]
Turla has used shellcode to download Meterpreter after compromising a victim.[6]
Turla RPC backdoors can be used to transfer files to/from victim machines on the local network.[5][7]
Turla has used the Registry to store encrypted payloads.[5][7]
Turla and its RPC backdoors have used APIs calls for various tasks related to subverting AMSI and accessing then executing commands through RPC and/or named pipes.[5]
Turla has used encryption (including salted 3DES via PowerSploit's Out-EncryptedScript.ps1), random variable names, and base64 encoding to obfuscate PowerShell commands and payloads.[5]
Based on comparison of Gazer versions, Turla made an effort to obfuscate strings in the malware that could be used as IoCs, including the mutex name and named pipe.[2]
Turla attempted to trick targets into clicking on a link featuring a seemingly legitimate domain from Adobe.com to download their malware and gain initial access.[4]
Turla has used spearphishing emails to deliver BrainTest as a malicious attachment.[8]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running processes using the tasklist /v command.[1] Turla RPC backdoors have also enumerated processes associated with specific open ports or named pipes.[5]
Turla has also used PowerSploit's Invoke-ReflectivePEInjection.ps1 to reflectively load a PowerShell payload into a random process on the victim system.[5]
Turla has used Metasploit to perform reflective DLL injection in order to escalate privileges.[6][9]
Turla RPC backdoors have included local UPnP RPC proxies.[5]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover information in the Windows Registry with the reg query command.[1] Turla has also retrieved PowerShell payloads hidden in Registry keys as well as checking keys associated with null session named pipes .[5]
Turla used net use commands to connect to lateral systems within a network.[1]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover remote systems on a local network using the net view and net view /DOMAIN commands.[1]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover operating system configuration details using the systeminfo and set commands.[1]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover network configuration details using the arp -a, nbtstat -n, nbtscan, and net config commands.[1][7] Turla RPC backdoors have also retrieved registered RPC interface information from process memory.[5]

Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover active local network connections using the netstat -an, net use, net file, and net session commands.[1] Turla RPC backdoors have also enumerated the IPv4 TCP connection table via the GetTcpTable2 API call.[5]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover running services and associated processes using the tasklist /svc command.[1]
Turla surveys a system upon check-in to discover the system time by using the net time command.[1]
Turla has used spearphishing via a link to get users to download and run their malware.[4]
A Turla JavaScript backdoor has used Google Apps Script as its C2 server.[4][6]
